metadata.title: Transbronchial microwave ablation of lung nodules with electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy guidance—a novel technique and initial experience with 30 cases

sections.abstract: Background: Microwave ablation of lung nodules may provide a faster, larger and more predictable ablation zone than other energy sources, while bronchoscopic transbronchial ablation has theoretical advantage of fewer pleural-based complications than percutaneous approach. Our study aims to determine whether the novel combination of bronchoscopic approach and microwave ablation in management of lung nodules is technically feasible, safe and effective. Methods: This is a retrospective analysis of a single center experience in electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy microwave ablation in a hybrid operating room. Patients had high surgical risks while lung nodules were either proven malignant or radiologically suspicious. Primary endpoints include technical feasibility and safety. Results: A total of 30 lung nodules from 25 patients were treated. Mean nodule size was 15.1 mm, and bronchus sign was present in 50%. Technical success was 100%, with some nodules requiring double ablation. Mean minimal ablation margin was 5.51 mm. The mean actual ablation zone volume was -21.4% compared to predicted, likely due to tissue contraction ranging 0-43%. No significant heat sink effect was observed. Mean hospital stay was 1.73 days, and only 1 patient stayed >3 days. Complications included pain (13.3%), pneumothorax requiring drainage (6.67%), post-ablation reaction/fever (6.67%), pleural effusion infection (3.33%) and hemoptysis (3.33%). After median follow-up of 12 months, none of the nodules had evidence of progression. Conclusions: Bronchoscopic transbronchial microwave ablation is safe and feasible for malignant lung nodules; prospective studies are warranted.
sections.methods: Single-centre retrospective analysis of consecutive patients undergoing electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy (ENB)-guided transbronchial microwave ablation (MWA) of malignant or radiologically suspicious lung nodules (March 2019-June 2020). Inclusion considered bronchus sign, peripheral location, tumour size <30 mm, and ≥5 mm from large vessels/mediastinum. Patients had biopsy-proven cancer/metastasis or radiologically suspicious nodules if biopsy not feasible/refused. Staging imaging performed; nodal disease ruled out with EBUS if indicated. Procedures were performed in a hybrid OR with cone-beam CT (CBCT) and fluoroscopy. ENB (SuperDimension) guided navigation; CrossCountry tool used for transbronchial access when needed; Emprint microwave catheter used for ablation. Predicted ablation margins were planned (minimum 5 mm). Post-ablation CBCT assessed actual margins; double ablation performed as needed. Follow-up with CT at 1, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months; local control assessed by radiologists using mRECIST. Statistical analyses: descriptive statistics; Student’s t test and chi-square tests as appropriate; significance threshold ≤0.05.
sections.results: Twenty-five patients (median Charlson comorbidity index 6) with 30 nodules were treated; mean maximal nodule diameter 15.1 mm (range 7-29). Bronchus sign present in 15/30 (50%). Mean procedural time (excluding concomitant biopsy) 126.3 minutes; median CBCT scans per case 7. Double ablation required in 4/30 (13.3%). Technical success was 100% (lesion included in ablation zone with adequate margin). Predicted minimal margin mean 6.63 mm (SD 2.89); actual minimal margin mean 5.51 mm (SD 2.48); no significant difference (P=0.086). Tissue contraction ranged 0-43%; actual ablation zone volume averaged -21.4% (SD 38.9%) vs predicted. Complications (per lesion): pain 4/30 (13.3%, CTCAE 1), pneumothorax requiring chest drain 2/30 (6.67%, CTCAE 3), post-ablation reaction/fever 2/30 (6.67%, CTCAE 1), hemoptysis 1/30 (3.33%, CTCAE 1), infected effusion 1/30 (3.33%, CTCAE 1). No abscess, BPF, hemothorax, arrhythmia, pneumonia, pulmonary edema, airway injury, unintended microwave burn, or procedure-related mortality. Mean hospital stay 1.73 days; one patient stayed 16 days due to pneumothorax with subsequent infected effusion. After median 12 months follow-up, no nodules progressed by mRECIST.

population.text: Adults with malignant or radiologically suspicious lung nodules at high surgical risk treated at a single tertiary center.
inclusion_criteria: Radiologically suspicious lung nodule on CT
High surgical risk or refusal of surgery
Preferably bronchus sign present, peripheral location, tumor size <30 mm
At least 5 mm from large vessels or mediastinal structures
Biopsy-proven lung cancer or metastasis OR radiologically suspicious if biopsy not feasible/refused and serial imaging supportive
T1N0M0 for primary lung cancers after staging
exclusion_criteria: Distant metastases on CT/PET-CT for primary lung cancer
Nodal involvement not excluded (if enlarged/hypermetabolic and not sampled)
Lesions near critical structures where thermal injury risk unacceptable (e.g., brachial plexus, phrenic nerve)

intervention.text: Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy-guided transbronchial microwave ablation
intervention.details: ENB navigation (SuperDimension) in a hybrid OR with CBCT/fluoroscopy. Transbronchial access created with CrossCountry when bronchus sign absent; biopsy performed when indicated. Microwave ablation with Emprint catheter (Thermosphere). Predicted ablation planning targeting ≥5 mm margins using PURE software. Post-ablation CBCT verification; repeat ablation (same position, pull-back, or bracket) as needed.

retrieval.summary_tldr: In 30 lung nodules treated with ENB-guided transbronchial microwave ablation, technical success was 100% with low complication rates and no local progression at a median 12 months.
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Demonstrates feasibility and safety of a non-transpleural bronchoscopic microwave ablation approach that may reduce pleural complications versus percutaneous methods in high-risk patients.
